THIS OPINION
  HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN
  ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Integon General
      Insurance Corporation, Appellant,
				v.
				George Jacob
      Shine, Kenneth G. Lane, Kenny Campbell, Neil R. Campbell, Jr. and Dorothy
      Merritt, as Personal Representative of the Estate of Jonah C. Merritt, Defendants,
				of whom:
				Kenneth G. Lane, Kenny Campbell, Neil R. Campbell, Jr.,
      and Dorothy Merritt, as Personal Representative of the Estate of Jonah C.
      Merritt are Respondents.
			
		
	


Appeal from Dillon County
Â James E. Lockemy, Circuit Court Judge
Memorandum Opinion No. 2008-MO-034
Heard June 24, 2008 â€“ Filed August 4, 2008Â Â  
REVERSED


	
		
			
				C.
  Mitchell Brown, William C. Wood, Jr., and A. Mattison Bogan, all of Nelson,
  Mullins, Riley & Scarborough, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				A.
  Glenn Greene, Jr., of Greene and Huggins, of Dillon, Robert Francis McMahan,
  Jr., of Harris and Graves, of Columbia, and William Jones Rivers, III, Â of
  Schurlknight and Rivers, of Florence, for Respondent.
			
		
	


PER CURIAM:Â 
  Appellant appeals an order finding coverage under its policy for an accident
  which occurred while its insured (driver) was operating a truck belonging to
  driverâ€™s father.Â  We hold that coverage is barred by an exclusion in the
  policy, and reverse.
FACTS
Driverâ€™s father owned the truck which was
  furnished for driverâ€™s motherâ€™s use. Â Driver, who was expressly forbidden to
  drive the truck by his parents, nevertheless took it and picked up the
  respondents.Â  When mother became aware that driver had taken the truck, she
  called him and ordered him to immediately bring it back to his parentsâ€™ house.Â 
  The accident occurred after this phone call.
Appellant brought
  this declaratory judgment action against driver, the surviving passengers, and
  the estate of the passenger who died as a result of the wreck.Â  Appellant made
  a number of arguments why its policy did not provide coverage under these
  circumstances.Â  The circuit court found against appellant on each issue.Â  We
  find it necessary to address only one.
ISSUE

	Did the
  circuit court err in holding that exclusion 18 did not apply so as to bar coverage
  under appellantâ€™s policy?

ANALYSIS
Appellant issued a
  policy to driver insuring driverâ€™s Buick automobile.Â  The circuit court held
  first that fatherâ€™s truck qualified as a temporary substitute vehicle under
  section 9c of the policy.Â  This section defines â€œYour Insured Autoâ€ to include:

	Any
  auto not owned by you while you are temporarily driving it as a substitute for
  any other auto described in this definition because of its withdrawal from
  normal use due to breakdown, repair, servicing, loss or destruction.

It is uncontested that the
  automobile insured under appellantâ€™s policy was inoperable at the time driver
  took his fatherâ€™s truck.Â  Moreover, the circuit court held that before a
  vehicle could qualify as a â€œYour Insured Auto,â€ it must be operated with
  permission.Â  The circuit court held that mother, a named insured under the
  truckâ€™s policy, had given driver permission to drive the truck when she ordered
  him to return it.[1]
The
  circuit court concluded that insurer could not rely on exclusion 18 which eliminates
  coverage for:

	18.  Bodily injury or property damage
  while using an auto without or beyond the scope of the ownerâ€™s expressed or
  implied permission.

The circuit court reasoned
  the exclusion was ambiguous because it only excludes coverage for
  non-permissive use of an â€œautoâ€ and does not specifically address whether it also
  applies to a vehicle meeting the policyâ€™s definition of â€œYour Insured Auto.â€Â  The
  circuit court again concluded that mother had given driver permission to drive
  the truck within the meaning of exclusion 18.
Appellant argues
  that under the exclusion the question is whether the owner of the automobile
  gave permission.Â  It contends there is simply no evidence that the truckâ€™s
  owner, driverâ€™s father, gave driver express or implied permission to take the
  truck.Â  In fact, the only evidence is that father explicitly prohibited driver,
  both verbally and in the truckâ€™s policy, from operating the vehicle.Â  Appellant
  argues, and we agree, that whether mother gave permission is irrelevant as its
  policy requires the auto be driven with the ownerâ€™s consent.Â  Insurer next
  contends there is no ambiguity in exclusion 18â€™s reference to â€œautoâ€ without
  also specifically referencing â€œYour Insured Auto.â€Â  We agree.Â  Under the
  definitions of the policy, all â€œYour Insured Autosâ€ are â€œautosâ€ but not all
  autos are â€œYour Insured Autos.â€ 
The
  term â€œautoâ€ in exclusion 18 means â€œa land motor vehicle or trailer designed for
  travel on public roads,â€[2] and necessarily includes those autos which also meet the limited definition of
  â€œYour Insured Auto.â€Â  There is no ambiguity in exclusion 18.Â  Furthermore, even
  assuming mother gave driver permission to operate the truck, that permission
  does not vitiate exclusion 18 which requires the ownerâ€™s (i.e. fatherâ€™s) permission.Â 
  The circuit court erred in failing to find exclusion 18 applies so as to deny
  coverage to respondents under the policy issued by appellant to driver.
CONCLUSION
The order finding
  appellantâ€™s policy provided coverage to the respondents is 
REVERSED.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, PLEICONES and BEATTY, JJ., concur.


[1] Whether motherâ€™s instruction constituted permission is not necessary to our
  resolution of this case, but we are doubtful of this conclusion.
[2] This is the driverâ€™s policyâ€™s definition of â€œauto.â€

ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF

Appeal from Charleston County

Memorandum Opinion No. 2008-MO-035
Submitted June 26, 2008 â€“ Filed August 4,

				Ms.
  Rachel P. Tucker-Cales, of Mt. Pleasant, pro se.
				Paul

PER
  CURIAM:Â  After careful review of the Appendix and briefs, we reverse the
  Court of Appeals decision[1] which affirmed the family court order holding petitioner in contempt.Â  Mosely
    v. Mosier, 279 S.C. 348, 306 S.E.2d 624 (1983)(parent who is financially
  unable to pay child support should not be held in contempt).
REVERSED.
TOAL,
  C.J., MOORE, WALLER, PLEICONES and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

THIS OPINION HAS NO
  PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN
  ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

  
    
      
        John A. Gore, Respondent,
        v.
        Beneficial
          Mortgage Co. of South Carolina, Petitioner.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI
To the Court of Appeals

Appeal From York County
  S. Jackson Kimball, III, Special Circuit
Court Judge 

Memorandum Opinion No. 2008-MO-036
  Submitted August 6, 2008 â€“ Filed August
11, 2008

VACATED IN PART


  
    
      
        C. Mitchell Brown, B. Rush Smith, III, and Thad H. Westbrook, all of
          Nelson Mullins Riley & Scarborough, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
        John Martin Foster, of Rock Hill, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:  Petitioner
  seeks a writ of certiorari to review the Court of Appealsâ€™ decision dismissing
  its appeal without prejudice.Â  We grant the petition as to the question of
  whether the Court of Appeals erred
  in including a finding related to the merits of the appeal in its opinion
  dismissing the appeal as interlocutory, dispense with further briefing, and vacate the decision of the Court
  of Appeals on that issue.Â  The petition for a writ of certiorari is denied as
  to petitionerâ€™s remaining questions.
In its opinion dismissing petitionerâ€™s
  appeal without prejudice, the Court of Appeals found the special circuit judge
  had the power to hear and rule upon respondentâ€™s motion to restore.Â  The Court
  of Appeals drew a distinction between a want of jurisdiction, in which case the
  court has no power to adjudicate, and a mistake in the exercise of
  jurisdiction, in which case the action of the trial court is not void, though
  it is subject to direct attack.
The
  Court of Appeals should not have included its finding concerning jurisdiction.Â 
  Even if the special circuit judge did not have jurisdiction, his order was not immediately appealable.Â  Deskins
    v. Boltin, 319 S.C. 356, 461 S.E.2d 395 (1995);Â  Woodard v. Westvaco
      Corp., 319 S.C. 240, 460 S.E.2d 392 (1995), overruled on other grounds
        by Saab v. S.C. State Univ., 350 S.C. 416, 567 S.E.2d 231 (2002).Â 
  Because the order was not immediately appealable, the Court of Appeals should
  not have addressed the merits.Â  Therefore, we vacate the portion of the Court
  of Appealsâ€™ decision addressing the special circuit judgeâ€™s jurisdiction.Â  
VACATED IN PART.
WALLER,
  ACTING CHIEF JUSTICE, PLEICONES, BEATTY and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur. TOAL, C.J.,
  not participating.
